item.title: Three Motets by Lully - French Baroque Music from Versailles (16.12.2021)
item.description:
Jean-Baptiste Lully is synonymous with the Versailles of Louis XIV with his music composed for and accompanying the grand occasions of the court. Three of the composer’s motets are performed from the royal chapel of Versailles. Programme :Jean-Baptiste Lully - Dies Irae Jean-Baptiste Lully - O Lachrymae fideles Jean-Baptiste Lully - De Profundis
From 16.12.2021 11:29

item.title: Gabriel Yared: Film Music - Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France (03.02.2021)
item.description:
With the composer in attendance, the French radio orchestra performs film scores from famous films such as The English Patient, The Talented Mr Ripley and Betty Blue.
From 03.02.2021 17:01

item.title: Barbara Hannigan Conducts Stravinsky and Weill - Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France (02.06.2021)
item.description:
Canadian soprano and conductor Barbara Hannigan conducts and sings with the French Radio Orchestra in a sensual programme celebrating the city of lights: gay Paris.Mezzo-soprano Julia Dawson, tenor Ziad Nehme and bass-baritone Douglas Williams also perform.ProgrammeIgor Stravinski – Pulcinella Kurt Weill – Youkali Jacques Offenbach - La Gaîté parisienne
From 02.06.2021 19:01

item.title: Mozart at the Hotel Sully (Paris) (05.02.2021)
item.description:
On a summer’s eve renowned pianist and conductor Lars Vogt leads the orchestre de chambre de Paris in a performance of Mozart’s much-loved Piano Concerto No. 9.
From 05.02.2021 00:00

item.title: Radio France Orchestra Christmas Concert - The Nutcracker and Swan Lake (24.03.2021)
item.description:
The orchestra performs works by Tchaikovsky and Georgy Sviridov, Mikko Franck conducts.
From 24.03.2021 17:00

item.title: Elementary, My Dear Celestin (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (26.11.2021)
item.description:
Written and directed by Floriane Bonanni, this playful work opens the doors to a world where music, poetry and surrealism meet. With musicians Jean-Claude Gengembre and Lucas Henri, narrated by Michel Robin.
From 26.11.2021 17:18

item.title: Astor Piazolla's Centenary - With Richard Galliano, Leonardo G. Alarcón and Mariana Flores (28.06.2021)
item.description:
The Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France pays homage to Astor Piazzolla (1921-1992) on what would have been his one hundredth birthday. The great Argentine tango composer is honoured by performances from accordion and bandoneon virtuosos Richard Galliano, William Sabatier and Lysandre Donoso as well as soprano Mariana Flores and the pianist Eric Le Sage.
From 28.06.2021 18:41

item.title: Martha Argerich Plays Prokofiev (11.06.2021)
item.description:
Star Argentine pianist Martha Argerich performs Prokofiev’s third piano concerto with the  French Radio Philharmonic Orchestra under the baton of conductor Myung-Whun Chung. Also on the programme is Prokofiev’s Ballet Suites from Rome and Juliet.
From 11.06.2021 17:00

item.title: Jacques in Release Party (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (13.04.2022)
item.description:
Between fiction and reality, French electro artist Jacques impresses in an offbeat episode of Release Party for the long-awaited release of his first album LIMPORTANCEDUVIDE.
From 13.04.2022 20:00

item.title: The Blaze - Live from the Nuits de Fourvière (12.01.2021)
item.description:
French electro duo the Blaze are in demand for their melancholic-euphoric sound, trademark dream-like music videos and seriously engaging live performances.
From 12.01.2021 17:00

item.title: L'Impératrice at the Paris Grand Palais - Passengers (16.04.2021)
item.description:
L’Impératrice bring a touch of French chic to their unique brand of electro with their new album Tako Tsubo delivering a host of danceable tunes to the cathedral-like space of the Grand Palais in Paris.Setlist : Masques Anomalie Bleue Sonate Pacifique Peur des Filles Voodoo? Erreur 404 Fou Submarine Hématome Vacances Agitations TropicalesMatahari
From 16.04.2021 15:46

item.title: 100 Years of Frank Sinatra (16.07.2021)
item.description:
Tom Gaebel, with his smart suit, polished shoes and perfect hair, is the German gentleman of swing. As a tribute to his master, Frank Sinatra, he performs with the WDR symphony orchestra, playing all the Sinatra classics including My Way, Strangers in the Night and New York, New York.
From 16.07.2021 15:25

item.title: "Dalibor" by Bedřich Smetana - At the Czech National Theatre (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (23.11.2021)
item.description:
As part of the ARTE Opera Season, the Czech National Theatre is showing a classic from the Czech repertoire: In this opera, Bedřich Smetana tells the story of an avenger figure from Czech history, whom he elevates to the rank of national hero. The opera is conducted by Jaroslav Kyzlink while Jiří Nekvasil signs the stage direction.
From 23.11.2021 05:01

item.title: Rossini: Il Barbiere di Siviglia - From the Vienna State Opera (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (27.11.2021)
item.description:
Rossini’s Il Barbiere di Siviglia ranks among the most popular and most successful works in the entire operatic canon. For his new staging of the work at the Vienna State Opera the director, actor and media artist Herbert Fritsch has assembled a star-studded cast that includes Juan Diego Flórez in the role of Count Almaviva, Ildar Abdrazakov as Don Basilio, Vasilisa Berzhanskaya as Rosina and Étie.....
From 27.11.2021 05:00

item.title: Prokofiev’s "The Fiery Angel" at the Teatro Real in Madrid (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (06.04.2022)
item.description:
Live from the Teatro Real in Madrid, an adaptation of Prokofiev’s flamboyant masterpiece by the ever-radical Calixto Bieito.
From 06.04.2022 12:00

item.title: Rameau: Hippolyte et Aricie - At the Opéra Comique in Paris (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (01.02.2022)
item.description:
In October 1733, the audience at the Académie Royale de Musique witnessed the birth of a revolutionary work: Hippolyte et Aricie. With its inventiveness and musical richness, Rameau’s opera marks a break in the history of French music. A similarly revolutionary duo – Jeanne Candel and Raphaël Pichon – get to grips with this work for the Opéra Comique.
From 01.02.2022 14:06

item.title: Lilly Wood and the Prick - Live at the Paris Olympia (08.12.2021)
item.description:
Folk duo Lily Wood and the Prick perform their new album Most Anything live from the legendary Paris Olympia.
From 08.12.2021 16:15

item.title: Sébastien Tellier - ARTE Concert Festival (19.01.2021)
item.description:
Sébastien Tellier is a singular artist with multiple facets: Darling of the Paris electro scene since the turn of the century and yet able to represent France at the kitsch fest of the Eurovison song contest in 2008. Performing at the ARTE Concert Festival on November 13 2020 at the release of his latest album ‘Simple Minds’.
From 19.01.2021 14:40

item.title: Morcheeba - Berlin Live (18.11.2021)
item.description:
London group Morcheeba have been going strong for 25 years with their unique chilled sound, most famously on their much celebrated 1998 album Big Calm. In 2018 they took to the Berlin stage to perform from their ninth album Blaze Away
From 18.11.2021 11:05

item.title: Cigarettes After Sex in Private Paris Concert (23.11.2020)
item.description:
In a special private concert in Paris, Greg Gonzales and his band perform from their newly released second album, ‘Cry’.
From 23.11.2020 18:15

item.title: Dope Lemon | Reeperbahn Festival 2019 (26.09.2019)
item.description:
Angus Stone’s recordings under the moniker Dope Lemon bring together psychedelia and indie-folk in a summer sound that evokes sunbaked Australia. 
From 26.09.2019 19:00

item.title: Berlin Live: Boy George & Culture Club (16.12.2021)
item.description:
For many, Culture Club epitomised 1980s pop music with global hits such as ‘Do You Really Want to Hurt Me?’ and ‘Karma Chameleon’. They take to the Berlin Live stage as part of an international tour promoting their new album ‘Life’.
From 16.12.2021 05:00

item.title: Ground Control - The Stranglers, The Jesus and Mary Chain, Keren Ann & Quatuor Debussy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.03.2022)
item.description:
In a disused Paris railway depot Christophe Cassel hosts two legendary British bands that are still going strong: The Stranglers and The Jesus and Mary Chain. They are joined by Keren Ann accompanied by her string quartet and the Australian whistler, Molly Lewis.
From 11.03.2022 19:42

item.title: Jules Verne's Extraordinary Indian Journey - City Country Culture (14.05.2021)
item.description:
In 1880, French writer Jules Verne published The Steam House, inspired by the landscapes and culture of northern India, a country he had never seen, which also portrayed the harsh realities of British colonialism. The novel narrates the duel between a fictional British colonel, Edward Munro, and real life rebel fighter, Nana Sahib.
From 14.05.2021 13:16

item.title: Ideology - Art of Gaming (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (20.02.2018)
item.description:
Gaming isn't all fun and games; there's an ideology and a world view behind each game. Trinity notes, as she plays her favourite games with political scientist Oliver Mauco, how often the protagonists are white men defending America from a foreign enemy. They then move on to Gal*Gun, and discuss the model of submissive femininity that it portrays. What if gaming was politics?
From 20.02.2018 13:18

item.title: New Zealand: The Voice of the Maori - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.12.2021)
item.description:
Te Ika a Maui, the North Island of New Zealand, is said to have been plucked from the Pacific by the demigod Maui. Writer Witi Ihimaera’s fiction is filled with the myths of the Maori people, with his novels reaching an international audience.
From 14.12.2021 13:27

item.title: Ernst Lubitsch and the Warsaw Resistance - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.02.2022)
item.description:
Warsaw seems to have preserved the medieval architecture of its old town from the ravages of time. Following the destruction caused by the Second World War, certain districts were rebuilt exactly as they were before. Ernst Lubitsch experimented with this reconstruction in Hollywood in 1942 with To Be Or Not To Be, his comic film poking fun at the Nazis.
From 11.02.2022 17:58

item.title: Polynesia Navigating with the Stars - City Country Culture (08.06.2021)
item.description:
At a time when the Romans did not venture far from the Mediterranean coast, the Polynesians crossed vast expanses of the Pacific Ocean in dugout canoes. It is said that they reached America long before Christopher Columbus navigating by the stars.
From 08.06.2021 10:37

item.title: City Country Culture - The Train That Unified The Catalans (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (12.04.2022)
item.description:
Since the 20th century, a yellow train has linked Villefranche-de-Conflent to Latour-de-Carol, offering travelers a unique panorama of the Eastern Pyrenees. Nicknamed canary for its color, this railway turned the lives of the Catalans of the north upside down, torn between the French Republic and the Kingdom of Spain.
From 12.04.2022 12:57

item.title: Twist - Remembrance Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (23.03.2022)
item.description:
What do we remember? And how do we live with our memories? With a major exhibition at the Carnavalet Museum in Paris about Marcel Proust, Twist investigates remembrance culture.
From 23.03.2022 16:35

item.title: Corsica: Asterix Island - City Country Culture (07.05.2021)
item.description:
When Asterix, Goscinny and Uderzo go to Corsica, it requires the cartoonists to go on a study visit to prepare, as they were careful not to upset the Corsicans, who are fiercely proud and notoriously anti-mainlander. The clichés in the comic are legion, but done with a sensitivity and humour.
From 07.05.2021 08:39

item.title: City Country Culture - Palm Springs, an Oasis of Hedonism (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (08.04.2022)
item.description:
In Southern California, in the middle of the desert, stands an oasis of pleasure. In the 1940s, Palm Springs was virgin land where the stars of architecture experimented and reinvented themselves. Today, the city is an open-air museum of modernism.
From 08.04.2022 12:27

item.title: Artist Collectives - The Ego Trip is Finished! - TWIST (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (01.01.2022)
item.description:
The solitary genius in art has long been venerated. But no longer. Make way for the artist collectives that are reimagining the art world and the role of the artist.  
From 01.01.2022 00:00

item.title: Edmond Rostand in the Pyrenees - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (17.12.2021)
item.description:
The chain of the Pyrenees, on the border with Spain, was a stunning backdrop for writer and poet Edmond Rostand. He visited the area throughout his life. It's here that he got his inspiration for his poetry collection Les Musardises, the work that heralded a series of successes.
From 17.12.2021 11:49

item.title: City Country Culture - Mexico: Indomitable Baja California (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (31.01.2022)
item.description:
For a long time, the Baja California peninsula was thought to be a land of legend, full of gold and pearls. These riches attracted Europeans with the Spanish conquistadors, French industrialists and Jesuit missionaries all coming. But the Mexican peninsular was inhabited long before the settlers came.
From 31.01.2022 10:02

item.title: Twist - The Pursuit of Freedom (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.04.2022)
item.description:
As a show of solidarity, Europe is displaying the colours of Ukraine, a country whose desire for democracy and freedom is perceived as a danger by Vladimir Putin's Russia. The pursuit of freedom is the subject of this episode of Twist. A desire shared by artists from all over the world.
From 11.04.2022 14:34

item.title: Geisha, the Ladies of Kyoto - City Country Culture (13.09.2021)
item.description:
Kyoto has been at the epicentre of Japanese culture for over a thousand years. Along its traditional alleys lined with wooden houses and sliding doors, geisha can still be spotted in their kimono and obi. At once works of art and artists at work, they embody a uniquely Japanese way of life.
From 13.09.2021 18:51

item.title: Woody Allen Eroticises Asturias - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.12.2021)
item.description:
A declaration of love from a New-York filmmaker to a Spanish city. Oviedo in Asturias, northern Spain served as the backdrop for Woody Allen’s comedic exploration of free love: Vicky Cristina Barcelona.
From 14.12.2021 16:04

item.title: City Country Culture - The Remains of the Day by Kazuo Ishiguro (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (10.02.2022)
item.description:
The novel The Remains of the Day charts the death throes of a bucolic, rustic England run by its aristocracy, on the eve of modernity. Japanese-British author Kazuo Ishiguro writes from the perspective of a butler who tours the countryside as he reflects on the estates he has served.
From 10.02.2022 12:35

item.title: Nikola Tesla Brings Light to Croatia - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (10.12.2021)
item.description:
The Serbo-Croatian engineer Nikola Tesla wanted to bring progress to his country: With the development of two-phase alternating current, he allowed for the nationwide transmission of electricity.
From 10.12.2021 15:54

item.title: Street Atelier: IBIG 2016 (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (13.11.2019)
item.description:
As festival season rolls around again, we take a look at last year's IBUG festival. Tasso, HNRX, Zonenkind, ZZNNart, along with more than 100 artists from all over the world were there. They ventured out of their usual urban landscape into transform the German countryside in Saxony, before opening to the public. This year's IBUG will be from the 25th August. So if we've inspired you, it's not too .....
From 13.11.2019 08:31

item.title: Auvers-sur-Oise: Vincent van Gogh's Wheat Fields - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.12.2021)
item.description:
Northwest of Paris, behind wheat fields and windswept plains, is the picturesque village of Auvers-sur-Oise, which depends on agriculture and tourism. At the end of the 19th century the painter Vincent van Gogh came to the village and spent the last few weeks before his death there. Despite his anguish, he created numerous works here in which he immortalised the nature of the village.
From 15.12.2021 20:05

item.title: Robert Doisneau in the Dordogne - City Country Culture (25.05.2021)
item.description:
Robert Doisneau is famed for his photos of Paris city life. But he also captured the happiness and serenity of life in a part of southwest France that he loved, the Dordogne.
From 25.05.2021 14:15

item.title: Kundera's Prague - City Country Culture (12.05.2021)
item.description:
The elusive and enigmatic nature of Prague is captured in Milan Kundera’s cult novel The Unbearable Lightness of Being. The Czech writer explores the philosophical vertigo of the difficult quest for freedom in human existence.
From 12.05.2021 16:16

item.title: Viral Humour - Telling Jokes in Corona Times (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.04.2021)
item.description:
Humour can help us through hard times. A look at the viral videos, songs and sketches that have filled the internet worldwide since the beginning of the pandemic and what this lockdown humour says about us.
From 16.04.2021 13:46

item.title: Gustave Courbet and the Open Horizons of the Languedoc - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.12.2021)
item.description:
With its ochre beaches and its Gallo-Roman remains, the Languedoc was a place full of inspiration for painter Gustave Courbet. The South of France, which he painted with realism, became for him a vast open-air workshop.
From 15.12.2021 20:11

item.title: City Country Culture - Lost in Translation - Sofia Coppola's Tokyo (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (29.03.2022)
item.description:
With its futuristic buildings, neon lights and gigantic advertising hoardings, downtown Tokyo can be a shock to foreign visitors. Sofia Coppola's 2003 film Lost in Translation has the shock of arriving in a strange land as one of its central themes.
From 29.03.2022 12:16

item.title: Women's Rights in 2022: Progress or Backslide? (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.03.2022)
item.description:
Women artists and thinkers give their view on women's progress. Alice Schwarzer, French icon of the women's movement, talks to us about 4,000 years of patriarchy and why women are still there are too nice. Viennese choreographer Florentina Holzinger doesn't give a damn about body norms and classic images of women. María Hesse, an author from Madrid, explores female sexuality.
From 14.03.2022 12:02

item.title: Egypt Takes Back Control of its Heritage - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (20.12.2021)
item.description:
In the past it was always Western archaeologists that led digs in Egypt and uncovered the marvellous treasures of Ancient Egypt. But today Egyptian academics are taking back control of their heritage.
From 20.12.2021 12:52

item.title: Twist - Walls, Fences, Barbed wire: The border is back! (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.03.2022)
item.description:
After the fall of the Iron Curtain in 1989, it seemed as if borders might disappear. Since the beginning of the 21st century, however, the opposite has been the case. Why is this? And how are artists reacting? Bianca Hauda goes to Berlin in search of answers.
From 15.03.2022 15:26

item.title: Tallinn, the Capital of Soviet Paranoia - City Country Culture (13.09.2021)
item.description:
A medieval town with winding streets and colorful facades, Tallinn is one of the best-preserved cities in Estonia. But its heritage has a dark underbelly. Under Communist rule for over four decades, it was overrun with KGB agents during the Cold War.
From 13.09.2021 19:02

item.title: City Country Culture - Annie Ernaux's Normandy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.02.2022)
item.description:
French writer Annie Ernaux grew up in Yvetot, a quiet small town in Normandy and studied in the regional capital of Rouen. It was here that she found the raw material for her literary work in novels such as Shame and The Years.
From 14.02.2022 15:58

item.title: City Country Culture - Lublln: The Polish Jerusalem (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (22.04.2022)
item.description:
Jews from all over the world come to the Polish city of Lublin to honour their Polish ancestors. As early as the 15th century, tens of thousands of them lived in the old city where they developed a rich and learned culture earning Lublin the moniker, the Polish Jerusalem.
From 22.04.2022 17:24

item.title: Rome with Hadrien and Marguerite Yourcenar - City Country Culture (08.09.2021)
item.description:
Writer Marguerite Yourcenar brought ancient Rome to life, “with narrow streets, crowded forums, bricks the color of old flesh.” She wrote of the imagined life of Emperor Hadrian in her novel Memoirs of Hadrian, published in 1951, now thought of as one of her masterpieces.
From 08.09.2021 09:39

item.title: Versus - Art of Gaming (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (25.11.2017)
item.description:
The multiplayer mode in gaming lets you play against your family, your friends, and even people you've never met before. How does playing against a real person change how you view the game, and how you play?
From 25.11.2017 00:00

item.title: City Country Culture - Kenya: Lion King Country (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (31.01.2022)
item.description:
In the early 1990s, the wilds of Kenya inspired Walt Disney Studios to create one of their most famous productions: The Lion King.
From 31.01.2022 18:13

item.title: Vivian Maier's Portraits of New York - City Country Culture (13.09.2021)
item.description:
Vivian Maier was an impatient, perhaps incompetent nanny... but in her time off, she was one of the most talented and prolific photographers of her generation. But she never sold a single photograph, or exhibited her work. Often, she wouldn't even get her pictures developed. It was only by chance that her hidden photographic genius was finally brought to light after her death.
From 13.09.2021 18:43

item.title: Giverny: Claude Monet's Water Lilies - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.12.2021)
item.description:
In a rural setting just to the north of Paris, Claude Monet made his home and created some of his best-known works, including his famous water lilies.
From 14.12.2021 16:38

item.title: James Bond in Perpignan - City Country Culture (04.06.2021)
item.description:
Is Perpignan an espionage hotspot? A look at how a famous fictional spy came to be in the Capital of French Catalonia.
From 04.06.2021 06:46

item.title: City Country Culture - Volver - Almodóvar Returns to La Mancha (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.02.2022)
item.description:
Volver (2006) starring Penelope Cruz is one of Pedro Almodovar’s most personal films. The iconoclastic director returns to his native region of La Mancha to pen a love letter to his mother who had recently died.
From 14.02.2022 09:16

item.title: Graham Green's Havana - City Country Culture (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.12.2021)
item.description:
In the 1950s, Havana was the Babylon of the Caribbean. At night it turned into a paradise for illegal business, hard liquor cocktails and wild parties. The traveler, journalist and occasional spy Graham Greene had already achieved notoriety with his work The Third Man, when he plunged into the turbulent nightlife of the Cuban capital with relish. His novel Our Man in Havana was published just a fe.....
From 16.12.2021 23:17

item.title: Slovenia: Hemingway's Farewell to Arms - City Country Culture (14.05.2021)
item.description:
The Soča river valley in Slovenia saw bloody battles during the first world war. Witness to this violence was a young Ernest Hemingway whose experiences informed his novel A Farewell to Arms.
From 14.05.2021 13:43

item.title: 4 Arab Women Comic Book Artists (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (17.08.2021)
item.description:
Four women comic book artists from the Arab World, Tunisian Nadia Khiari, Lebanese Lena Merhej, Moroccan Zainab Fasiki and Egyptian Deena Mohamed open the doors of their studios and tell us about their experiences and their struggles. Ten years after the beginning of the Arab Spring how can they express themselves in the medium as Arab women?
From 17.08.2021 05:00

item.title: Belgium: Beer Paradise - City Country Culture (05.05.2021)
item.description:
UNESCO recognised Belgian beer is the result of an ancestral know-how which today produces nearly 1500 varieties. 
From 05.05.2021 16:47

item.title: Egotrip - Art of Gaming (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (22.11.2017)
item.description:
What does the choice of avatar tell us about the human being behind it? A mirror of ourselves or a reinvention? We analyse the relationship between gamer and on-screen character.
From 22.11.2017 00:00

item.title: Deauville, the Seaside Town that Inspired Coco Chanel - City Country Culture (10.05.2021)
item.description:
Since the end of the 19th century, Deauville has been an upper class beach resort for France's well-to-do, and it was here that Gabrielle Chanel was inspired to create her characteristic style that freed women from the constraints of corsets, frills and many-layered frocks.
From 10.05.2021 16:09

item.title: Sappho and Lesbos - City Country Culture (06.07.2021)
item.description:
On the Aegean island of Lesbo a women celebrates love between women for the first time in literature, around the 6th century BC. Sappho revealed a world of ardent desire and heartache through her lyric poetry.
From 06.07.2021 12:23

item.title: Become Rich! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.11.2021)
item.description:
Why is it so important for some to show that they have money? Does wealth make you happy? Or maybe true wealth is having nothing at all? We go to the streets of Berlin to talk to the people of the city about wealth, minimalism and freedom.
From 30.11.2021 12:53

item.title: The Occult: is the Supernatural a Natural Part of Life? - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (23.10.2021)
item.description:
What if our lives were governed by the supernatural? Why do so many people feel the urge to connect with gods, angels and energies? The occult doesn't have a great reputation, but how bad is it really? In this episode, Jan searches for answers to his metaphysical doubts.
From 23.10.2021 05:00

item.title: Is Sport Meaningless? - Philosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.03.2021)
item.description:
Where does the cliché of the dumb athlete come from? Is cycling essentially futile? For this episode on intelligence and the meaning of sport, Raphaël Enthoven talks with Guillaume Martin, cyclist and philosopher, as well as Chantal Jouanno, former Minister of Sports.
From 11.03.2021 17:29

item.title: Face What’s Foreign to You! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (22.11.2020)
item.description:
Some people embrace a multicultural society with open arms while others are fearful and want to build walls. Why does our behaviour change when we meet strangers? Reflections on difference, belonging and foreignness.
From 22.11.2020 08:00

item.title: Does Consoling the Bereaved Even Work? - Philosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.04.2021)
item.description:
The pandemic has stopped some people from attending the funerals of their loved ones, or forced them into low key, socially distanced affairs. Raphaël Enthoven explores the psychological impact on missing out on those grief rituals. But if they don't help lessen the pain, what is the point of them? Grief therapist Sophie Poupard-Bonnet and philosopher Vincent Delecroix explore what it means to gri.....
From 09.04.2021 20:38

item.title: Visions of the Future - Art, Genetics and Artificial Intelligence (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (01.12.2019)
item.description:
Current research on genetics and artificial intelligence promises to revolutionise our world. But how is the art world engaging with the latest technology and advances in science? A focus on artists who are pushing boundaries and revealing the future.
From 01.12.2019 00:00

item.title: Find Your Faith! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (27.07.2020)
item.description:
Is everyone capable of faith? Streetphilosophy goes in search of belief with philosopher Elena Loevskaya and astrophysicist Noam Libeskind.
From 27.07.2020 11:38

item.title: Listen to Your Emotions! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.12.2020)
item.description:
Should we let ourselves by guided by our emotions in life? Or should we listen to reason?  Ronja asks her fellow Berliners to find out the answers.
From 14.12.2020 16:34

item.title: Outrage! - Philosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.04.2022)
item.description:
Why, in the era of twitter and other social media, do we get angry so often? Why are we outraged by events in the world today? Raphaël Enthoven debates the notion of outrage with professor Laurent de Sutter and Cécile Duflot, director of Oxfam France.
From 14.04.2022 07:01

item.title: Love! But how? - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (20.12.2020)
item.description:
Ronja von Ronne explores different types of relationships and questions the nature of love and our search for it. Can love exist between two people, or between three? And what of our love for ourselves, or indeed the unconditional love we hold for our pets?
From 20.12.2020 08:00

item.title: Be Antifragile! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.11.2021)
item.description:
The pandemic, the climate emergency ... Everything seems extremely fragile at the moment. But is it possible to grow with crises? If so, what is the key? How can adaptability and courage make you more resilient?
From 09.11.2021 16:02

item.title: Living for Work - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (19.11.2020)
item.description:
Working to live or living to work. In a capitalist society characterised by ever-increasing mechanisation, what meaning can we give to our daily grind? Ronja von Rönne finds out by meeting lawyers, circus performers and old-time taxi drivers.
From 19.11.2020 08:00

item.title: Streetphilosophy - Live For Fame (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.11.2020)
item.description:
A physical and philosophical meandering through the streets of Berlin as presenter Jonas Bosslet asks: why do people put themselves centre stage on social networks? What does it mean for how we view others - and ourselves? How can this endless thirst for glory and adulation be explained?
From 16.11.2020 08:00

item.title: Use Your Time! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.11.2020)
item.description:
Time stands still or time flies. Why does our perception of time passing vary according to how we spend it? Exploring the idea of time in twenty-six minutes.
From 09.11.2020 08:00

item.title: How to Solve a Moral Dilemma - Philosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (01.02.2021)
item.description:
What should we do when there is a shortage of hospital beds due to the COVID-19 health crisis? Should older patients, more at risk, be prioritised? Can we justify coronavirus lockdowns which save older citizens’ lives while ruining the economic prospects of the younger generation? Raphaël Enthoven explores the moral dilemmas of today’s world.
From 01.02.2021 12:26

item.title: Making Decisions - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (31.10.2020)
item.description:
Should we reason with ourselves when making decisions or just go with our gut? Ronja meets a psychologist, an astrologist and a soldier to talk about how to make up one’s mind.
From 31.10.2020 05:00

item.title: Learning to Lose - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (13.12.2020)
item.description:
Loss challenges us as human beings. Losing loved-ones, losing our independence or even the thought of losing our lives can be very difficult. How can we live fully and learn from the pain of loss without it taking over our lives? Ronja Von Rönne finds answers by talking to an author, a boxer, a visually impaired gallerist and a 70 year-old techno DJ.
From 13.12.2020 08:00

item.title: Fifty Shades... of Love - Philosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.04.2022)
item.description:
There is erotic love, familial love, love of a city and love of humanity. Raphaël Enthoven debates with Laure Barillas, specialist in the philosophy of Vladimir Jankélévitch, and Luc-Thomas Somme, a Dominican priest.
From 14.04.2022 07:01

item.title: Use Technology! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (06.12.2020)
item.description:
Does technological progress help or hinder us as individuals? Jonas finds out by meeting a cycling enthusiast and a jujitsu champion.
From 06.12.2020 08:00

item.title: Be Wild! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (23.05.2021)
item.description:
Leave behind society, go out into nature and find again your true wild self? In our controlled societies, the idea is tempting. Ronja von Rönne goes to meet a biker gang, for whom being wild is a way of life.
From 23.05.2021 08:00

item.title: Ecology: The Enemy of Progress? - Philosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.04.2022)
item.description:
The pandemic saw us press pause on consumption and carbon emissions, and many ecologists celebrated the fact that the planet was being given a much-needed break.Raphaël Enthoven talks with the philosopher Dominique Bourg and the journalist Ferghane Azihari about being green in the modern world.
From 14.04.2022 07:01

item.title: Embrace Your Sexuality! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (20.11.2021)
item.description:
How does sex, identity and self-expression interlace? We explore this muli-faceted question through the lives of multiple Berliners, starting with four voguing performers who've created a safe space for themselves, and an asexual model who posts sexy pictures online. Next we visit a hypersexual couple and discover puppy play with Marion and Leo.
From 20.11.2021 05:00

item.title: Live your Desires! But How? - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (02.07.2021)
item.description:
Streetphilosophy roams the streets of Berlin to find answers to philosophical questions. In this episode Ronja von Rönne asks: What is happiness? How do I please myself while also pleasing others? And how can I realise my desires?
From 02.07.2021 17:07

item.title: Find the Funny Side! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.10.2021)
item.description:
Ronja tries to find out what humour really is by attempting to be a stand-up comedian. Along the way she gets advice from Polish comedian Kat Nip, satirical political party Die Partei, and talks to philosopher Marco Weimer about the subversive nature of humour.
From 16.10.2021 05:00

item.title: Offended Identities? - Philosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.03.2021)
item.description:
Raphaël Enthoven explores the notion of black identity with Tania de Montaigne, author of "Assignation - Black people do not exist", and Lilian Thuram, former footballer and author of "White Thought".
From 15.03.2021 19:48

item.title: Have No Fear! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (29.07.2021)
item.description:
For better or worse, fear is part of our lives. Ronja von Rönne finds out what scares Berliners the most. Fear is often distressing but can it be a positive emotion?
From 29.07.2021 15:52

item.title: Esra Karakaya Talks Growth Criticism - Time to Question (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.07.2020)
item.description:
Esra Karakaya is a journalist and founder of the BlackRockTalk platform. She talks to researcher Christian Kabengele about the concept of growth ‘criticism’, a school or thought that questions governments' focus on economic growth.
From 15.07.2020 12:00

item.title: Behind the Mask - Philosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.04.2022)
item.description:
The mask is both a symbol of altruism and civicism, and of personal liberty curtailed. Raphaël Enthoven explores its many paradoxes with the philosophy researcher Elsa Novelli and the Secretary of State Sophie Cluzel in charge of People with Disabilities.
From 14.04.2022 07:01

item.title: Utopia - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (27.07.2020)
item.description:
Do human beings have the vision to create utopia? And if so, should we start out small or think really big? From digital algorithms to old-fashioned local politics, Streetphilosophy asks: how do we create a better world? 
From 27.07.2020 11:30

item.title: The Importance of Being Educated - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (05.12.2021)
item.description:
"The aim of education is to form beings adapted to a system," said philosopher Johannes Winter. But Rousseau convinced us that children must be free to develop as they wish. Can we educate entire societies? Ronja discusses the idea with a lifeguard from Berlin, Extinction Rebellion activists and a couple of artists.
From 05.12.2021 21:59

item.title: Find your Fetish! - Streetphilosophy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.01.2021)
item.description:
Why do people develop fetishes? One person gets a thrill from leather outfits, another loves licking feet, or obsessively collecting shoes.  Are fetishes in our nature? Or are they perversions that we should free ourselves from?
From 09.01.2021 05:00

item.title: Ecko Bazz / Political Bodies / Jean Lecointre / Alexeï German Jr - Tracks (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (05.12.2021)
item.description:
Ugandan MC Ecko Bazz offers up the soundtrack of his worst nightmares. Also in the programme: Guatemalan artist and poet Regina José Galindo and Afghan artist Kubra Khademi, Jean Lecointre, the Frankenstein of collage and Russian filmmaker Alexei Guerman Jr.
From 05.12.2021 22:00

item.title: The Splendid Ones by Meryem-Bahia Arfaoui - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (05.02.2022)
item.description:
Social housing in France has a bad reputation, and its residents often isolated by mainstream society. These girls tell of how their mothers struggled to survive, and of the strong feeling of community on the estate. But those social ties are under threat as gentrification looms. 
From 05.02.2022 11:02

item.title: Ana by Séraphine Charpentier-Andre - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
24-year-old Anaëlle looks after 35 single men in a center for asylum seekers. She takes care of their administrative needs, their doctor's appointments and day-to-day admin. Above all, she listens to each migrant's story and then prepares them for the interview with the French asylum authority OFPRA, which decides whether to not to grant them refugee status.
From 04.02.2022 10:54

item.title: #AMINORMAL (1/8) - How to Boost Your Libido (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.01.2022)
item.description:
You thought that once you find the right person it's 'happy ever after' in life and in the bedroom? But in actual fact, as these women affirm, desire ebbs and flows. It's normal! Or is it? The DSM calls low sex drive in women “female desire disorder”. But given that women often do the lion's share of domestic tasks and childcare on top of their paid work, maybe this is a medical diagnosis... for a.....
From 30.01.2022 11:52

item.title: We Wear the Crown - 40 Years of German Rap (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (12.11.2021)
item.description:
In 1980, Thomas Gottschalk rapped a German version of Rappers Delight on TV. Next, Falco had a worldwide hit with Der Kommissar. It was the start of a German rap movement, and breakdancing swept over Germany. We take a nostalgic look back on the 80s and 90s cool kids of rap.
From 12.11.2021 14:39

item.title: Black Belt Matters - Kung Fu Revolution(s) (4/6) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (20.09.2021)
item.description:
Since the 1970s martial arts have been a strong source of inspiration for young black Americans, from early Blaxploitation films to the Black Panthers to hip-hop.
From 20.09.2021 17:14

item.title: Tracks - Russian Artists Against the War (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.04.2022)
item.description:
Russian artists have two choices: silence, or exile. There's been a mass creative exodus in recent weeks, including Russian rap stars like Face and Oxxxymiron. Art rockers IC3PEAK post protest videos that would get them arrested in Russia. TikTok star Nikita Sass bravely continues to post his opinion and stays. Few dare to do that.
From 04.04.2022 10:03

item.title: Sisters by Lorraine David and Lola Pidoux - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
Not far from the Paris ring road in the suburb of Vanves, stands the Sainte Bathilde priory. Here, twenty-two nuns live in seclusion according to the rule of Saint Benedict. Their days are punctuated by bells, prayer, and work.
From 04.02.2022 10:45

item.title: The Love Story of a Body by Lilia Lerondeau - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
Your life, or your breasts. For Valérie, it was no contest. When she got breast cancer, she had both breasts removed entirely and decided not to have reconstructive sugery. Instead she learnt to live with, and even love, her scars. The cancer could come back: but for now, she's happy and proud of her body.
From 04.02.2022 10:39

item.title: South Africa - Girlhood - Women in Rap (2/4) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (02.12.2021)
item.description:
Dee Koala and Dope Saint Jude are young rappers from the Cape region of South Africa. Dope decided to move to London to pursue her musical career whilst Dee has stayed in her local community.
From 02.12.2021 14:26

item.title: In-Game Photography - Art of Gaming (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (02.02.2022)
item.description:
Video game photographer Martin Geisler shows us with examples from “Skyrim”, “the Hunter” and “Squad” that photography within gameplay has become as art form.
From 02.02.2022 08:01

item.title: Tigresses and Dragons - Kung Fu Revolution(s) (3/6) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (20.09.2021)
item.description:
Martial arts heroines played by the intrepid Cheng Pei and Hsu Feng in the 1960s anticipated modern Hollywood heroines by decades. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (2000) introduced fighting female characters to the West. Today, the adventure continues with new martial arts movies starring women including Liu Yifei in Disney’s global hit Mulan.
From 20.09.2021 16:42

item.title: Klapping / Emilie Brout & Maxime Marion / Sisto / Ami Yerewolo - Tracks (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (07.12.2021)
item.description:
The art of klapping, where dance meets football.  Also in the programme: Artist couple Emilie Brout and Maxime Marion harvest the internet. Spanish multi-media artist Pascual Sisto talks about his new film ‘John and the Hole’ and Ami Yerewolo raps in Bambara to traditional African music.
From 07.12.2021 15:10

item.title: Emoji Nation (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.12.2021)
item.description:
How did emojis conquer the world? "Think big, start small." Probably that’s what they would say if they could talk. So we asked their creators: from Shigetaka Kurita, designer of the first emojis, to Rayouf Alhumedhi, who created the hijab emoji. 🧕
From 15.12.2021 05:00

item.title: Being Born a Girl by - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.02.2022)
item.description:
What does being born a girl mean in the 2020s? Three women from three continents share their stories. In Japan, Kumi recounts the assaults she experienced in the Tokyo underground when she was a teenager. In Burkina Faso, Ibrahim talks about the pressure of early marriages. In France, Marie talks about the domestic violence she endured.
From 14.02.2022 09:09

item.title: #AMINORMAL (6/8) - How to Live With a Hoarder (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.01.2022)
item.description:
Enthusiasts present their collections of stones, Star Wars, dolls, axes and even bones… and their spouses are supposed to just make room! They thought they were normal, except if they were read the diagnosis of the DSM, the bible of mental health, they might recognise themselves. The mania for excessively accumulating objects is qualified as a disorder!
From 30.01.2022 12:16

item.title: Bubble by Jessica Bros - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (05.02.2022)
item.description:
After several years abroad, entrepreneur Tiffany, 41, returned to Paris and decided to become a mum - despite being single. She had to go abroad for her treatment, as in France single women were not allowed access to assisted reproductive technology.
From 05.02.2022 10:30

item.title: #AMINORMAL (3/8) - ADHD in Older People (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.01.2022)
item.description:
These seniors admit that they talk too much, forget appointments and have been bored since they retired. Like all grandparents would tell us: they are getting old, so it's normal. But the DSM says that these could be signs of ADHD.
From 30.01.2022 12:03

item.title: The City of Others - By Roser Corella - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (08.02.2022)
item.description:
Almost daily a steady stream of young girls queues up at Addis Ababa and Dhaka international airport, destination Beirut. all long for a new life abroad with promises of high wages and a good job. Yet for most that dream becomes a nightmare as they forced into prostitution or a slave-like existence as housemaids working 20 hour days without pay. A thought-provoking look of the exploitative working.....
From 08.02.2022 14:12

item.title: #AMINORMAL (2/8) - Managing a Long Distance Relationship (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.01.2022)
item.description:
Is it possible to have an addiction to the internet when most daily tasks require the Internet? That's especially true for couples who've only ever met online and depend on technology to keep the relationship going. For them, spending more than 7 hours a day on their phone is normal. But the DSM would describe them as addicts.
From 30.01.2022 11:59

item.title: #AMINORMAL (4/8) - How to Survive Your Period (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.01.2022)
item.description:
The womb may create life, but it can also make life pretty miserable. The women interviewed here tell us how they experience bad mood swings before menstruation. This is normal unless you read the DSM: after “premenstrual syndrome”, the latest edition establishes a more severe disorder, known as premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD).
From 30.01.2022 12:08

item.title: The Man Who Washed in the River by Marzieh Namini - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (05.02.2022)
item.description:
Tehran, 2021. Drug addicts take part in group therapy. Day by day they learn to put their addiction into words; they find the courage to tell their story and remember the moment they made the decision to get off drugs.
From 05.02.2022 10:41

item.title: It's Yours - The Story of Hip Hop and the Internet (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (18.10.2021)
item.description:
In the early 2000s, the successes of US hip-hop artists like Lil B, Wiz Khalifa or Tyler The Creator, was thanks to their mastery of the Internet. They broke away from traditional sales models, and the hip-hop community forged its own way into mainstream recognition without the help of music execs.
From 18.10.2021 18:41

item.title: Disability and Pop Culture - Tracks (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (01.01.2022)
item.description:
Whether it's extreme sports, stand-up comedy, breakdancing or music, disability isn’t an obstacle to pursuing your passion. Tracks' meets Aaron Fotheringham, Dergin Tokmak and Pone to understand the power of pop culture in empowering 'invisible' minorities.
From 01.01.2022 00:00

item.title: Emotionally Dependent Anonymous by Angéla Nichon - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.01.2022)
item.description:
Alexandre's relationships fill an inner void, and his unhealthy attitude to relationships has led him down the path of emotional dependence. He decided to regain his autonomy, and wean himself off of his addiction to others.
From 30.01.2022 12:35

item.title: Morocco - Girlhood - Women in Rap (4/4) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (02.12.2021)
item.description:
Being a female rapper in Morocco is difficult in what is still a male dominated society. Krtas Nssa, voted best female rapper in Morocco in 2019, has chosen to live in Belgium. Khtek decided to stay in Rabat and change mentalities from inside the country.
From 02.12.2021 17:47

item.title: Total Immersion Special - Tracks (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (06.01.2022)
item.description:
A total immersion into the world of sound: Sound engineer Nicolas Becker explains his craft featured in films such as Sound of Metal and La Haine. FUJIIIIIIITA, makes his own instruments to let his audience have new sound experiences. With more than 500 films (and 500,000 photographs), Boris Lehman is the first-person filmmaker par excellence.
From 06.01.2022 16:41

item.title: Germany - Girlhood - Women in Rap (1/4) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (01.12.2021)
item.description:
Yetundey is originally from Leipzig and mixes styles and influences. Layla Boe wants to make the German language smoother in her music.
From 01.12.2021 15:42

item.title: Emojis: The End of Language? (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.12.2021)
item.description:
Friendly and innocent, almost anything and everything can be said with emojis. To decipher this pop esperanto, Pierre Halté, doctor of Language Science and Evgeny Morozov, writer and researcher, track down the influence of these small pictograms on our language and our culture. 🕵️
From 15.12.2021 05:00

item.title: Holo Life - Avatars and Holograms - Tracks (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (05.01.2022)
item.description:
Tracks dives into the world of augmented reality, avatars and hologram performances. With ABBA and others pioneering avatar performance, is nostalgia pushing technology forward? Also in the programme: Synth pop French musician Oklou and German DJ, Boys Noize.
From 05.01.2022 18:16

item.title: Arno: Dancing Inside My Head (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (23.04.2022)
item.description:
At age 67, Arno's prolific career includes 35 albums and numerous tours. A sensitive portrait of the king of Belgian rock. His is a complex personality; unlike the Kardashians, he doesn't want to reveal all. 
From 23.04.2022 22:15

item.title: Oh Boy by Cannelle Favier-Benito and Alice Tubert - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
For three years James funded his nomadic lifestyle by filming porn videos with his girlfriend. But when they break up, his personal crisis is also professional. Making videos with other women doesn't interest him: he wants to continue alone and see if his viewers will stick with him.
From 04.02.2022 10:34

item.title: The Matrix and Robot Samourais - Kung Fu Revolution(s) (6/6) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (21.09.2021)
item.description:
In The Matrix, Neo and Morpheus are the warrior monks of a Shaolin temple 2.0. With the digital revolution, the enemy takes on more devious forms, even infiltrating inside ourselves!
From 21.09.2021 18:33

item.title: BBC Crew Paris - The Rise of Graffiti Writing (2/6) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (28.03.2022)
item.description:
The BBC crew around Jay One, Skki and Ash is one of the most influential pioneers in French graffiti. They were some of the first artists in Europe to develop their own style and break free from New York influence.
From 28.03.2022 10:00

item.title: At the Heart of Emoji Valley (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.12.2021)
item.description:
You couldn't let emoji roam the web unfettered and out of control. After many iterations they are now encoded in the Unicode standard. And, for better or for worse, the fate of the little yellow men is now under the purview of the Unicode Consortium, an organisation based in Silicon Valley.
From 15.12.2021 05:00

item.title: #AMINORMAL (5/8) - How to Make Friends With Food (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (31.01.2022)
item.description:
Do you sometimes secretly eat so much that your stomach hurts? These interviews show that you are not alone. And if a lot of people do that, it's kind of normal, isn't it? The Handbook of Mental Disorders (DSM) sees it differently. Binge eating is a disorder, and it's the most common eating disorder in the US!
From 31.01.2022 14:40

item.title: The Day and Hour by Catherine Pamart - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
Madame Pamart is 80 and she's ready to die. Her daughter, director Catherine, decides to document their journey. Her mother, suffering from multiple chronic illnesses, wants her children to help her to go to Switzerland for assisted suicide. Somewhat disturbed by her final request for help, Catherine must none the less come to terms with her choice.
From 04.02.2022 09:10

item.title: Local Street Style - The Rise of Graffiti Writing (4/6) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (28.03.2022)
item.description:
Darco and Gawki got to know FBI-Crew in 1985 in Paris. They become an integral part of the Paris graffiti movement with a style typical of that city. Paris was the center of the European scene, but graffiti artists in Munich, Hamburg, Amsterdam and Copenhagen were also developing their own takes on the trend.
From 28.03.2022 10:00

item.title: Tracks: Songwriting Special - Pop Music: The Great Recycling Business (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.04.2022)
item.description:
Have you ever wondered why pop songs sometimes sound a little too familiar? Welcome to the world of pop-recycling where borrowing, sampling and interpolation are the order of the day. Featuring interviews with Placebo, Ed Sheeran, Charlie XCX and Lauv.
From 11.04.2022 15:20

item.title: Maternal Regret by Lolita Rive - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
"If I had to do it again, I wouldn't do it again, that's for sure." Julie, 36, regrets becoming a mum. She lives in Bordeaux with her 10-year-old daughter and her husband, Matthieu. She loves her child but motherhood is just not for her: she doesn't like kid's games, and she hates all the time constraints and responsabilities.
From 04.02.2022 09:49

item.title: Elana by Erika Haglund - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
Elana turns 18 this year. She divides her time between her life between the medical-professional institute where she is an apprentice, and her first internships in an ESAT (a protected work establishment for disabled workers). But what Elana prefers above all is escaping life on her aerial hoop...
From 04.02.2022 10:52

item.title: #AMINORMAL (7/8) - How to Flirt When You're Shy (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.01.2022)
item.description:
They've always been shy and they've struggled with the feeling of a tight throat, blushing, and the deep fear of rejection that makes conversation difficult. Is this type of shy natural and normal, or is it social anxiety as defined in the DSM?
From 30.01.2022 12:20

item.title: Nobody Owns Me by Anouk Meissner - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
Irina lives in a squat with her boyfriend, and dog. She talks about why she ended up on the street, how she learned to do without others, and what writing means to her. She dreams of living a normal life.
From 04.02.2022 09:58

item.title: To life - by Stefanie Gartmann - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (08.02.2022)
item.description:
Lene lives in a remote fjord in Iceland. For more than thirty-five years, she has been creating art with organic animal material: skins, horse hair, bones. "When a skin is tanned and ready” Lene explains, “I can feel a little bit of the life coming back”.
From 08.02.2022 14:36

item.title: The Scent of France by Eve-Chems De Brouwer - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.02.2022)
item.description:
L. is 15 and going through the usual teenage rebellion phase, and her mother has a plan to put a stop to it. Telling her daughter that they are going on holiday, she takes her back 'home'... and leaves her there to marry a stranger.
From 04.02.2022 10:07

item.title: Iye Ka'i by Olivia Braconnier - The Female Directors Documentary Competition (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (05.02.2022)
item.description:
French Guiana, on the border with Brazil: Ka'i aka Isabelle is a young woman from the Wayãpi tribe. She lives in her family's village growing cassava. She studied and worked in the city, but chose to go home when she got pregnant with her first child.
From 05.02.2022 10:47

item.title: Saudi Arabia: The West - Unknown Arabia (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (22.11.2021)
item.description:
Saudi Arabia is reputed to be one of the richest and most conservative nations on the planet. But how do its citizens live today?
From 22.11.2021 14:45

item.title: Saudi Arabia: The East - Unknown Arabia (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (24.11.2021)
item.description:
Saudi Arabia has many surprises in store for visitors. Around the gulf city of Dammam in the east, huge oil fields have made the country's fortune. Further inland, the flea market in the capital, Riyadh, attracts businessmen, day labourers and billionaires who all come to haggle.
From 24.11.2021 15:03

item.title: United Arab Emirates - Unknown Arabia (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (24.11.2021)
item.description:
The United Arab Emirates includes the sci-fi like cities of Abu Dhabi and Dubai with their breath taking towers and impressive beach resorts. It is also a land of expats with residents from over two hundred different nations.
From 24.11.2021 14:34

item.title: Fairytale Oman - Unknown Arabia (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (22.11.2021)
item.description:
In recent years Oman has been opening up to western tourists. What awaits them is a land of mountains, deserts, fjords, and pristine beaches.
From 22.11.2021 15:47

item.title: Small Neighbours: Bahrain, Qatar, Kuwait - Unknown Arabia (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (15.11.2021)
item.description:
The three smalles states on the Persian Gulf could not be more different: Qatar is the richest country on Earth, conservative, and attached to its traditions whereas Bahrain is cosmopolitan and liberal. Kuwait is particularly pristine with some of the best food in Arabia.
From 15.11.2021 15:30

item.title: Anas Modamani, and a Fateful Selfie - Domino Effect (1/4) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (24.08.2021)
item.description:
One small action can lead to big consequences. This is the story of how Anas Modamani, a Syrian refugee, had his life turned upside after he took a picture with Chancellor Angela Merkel. He went on to take Facebook to court and Germany fined the tech over a million euros.
From 24.08.2021 20:19

item.title: Heldenplatz 1988: An Austrian Scandal - Great Speeches: Thomas Bernhard (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (30.07.2018)
item.description:
Autumn 1988. 50 years after Hitler’s Anschluss, Austria’s most famous writer penned a scathing attack on his country’s anti-Semitism in his play Heldenplatz, that caused outrage. 30 years later, how relevant is Bernhard’s work?
From 30.07.2018 19:00

item.title: Ahed Tamimi, the Kid Activist - Domino Effect (4/4) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (24.08.2021)
item.description:
Ahed Tamimi grew up in a small village in occupied Palestine, and protest was in her blood. She had grown up yelling at Israeli soldiers and demonstrating for a free Palestine. So the day that soliders showed up on her family’s property, she didn’t hesitate : she marched up to them and slapped them. Her anger would land her in prison and make her an icon of the resistance.
From 24.08.2021 20:22

item.title: Marie Laguerre, Street Harassment Hero - Domino Effect (2/4) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (24.08.2021)
item.description:
Maire Laguerre was walking home from work when she was sexually harassed by a man in the street. When she told her aggressor to get lost, he threw an ashtray at her and punched her in the face. She decided to post the video of her attack online and it went viral, eventually triggering a change in street harassment laws in France.
From 24.08.2021 20:19

item.title: YES, EQUAL! The Road to Equality - Great Speeches - Panti Bliss (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (26.06.2018)
item.description:
In February 2014 Panti Bliss, aka Rory O’Neill, spoke at Dublin's Abbey theatre where he denounced homophobia. The speech became an internet sensation and made Panti Bliss a symbol of the gay rights struggle in Ireland.
From 26.06.2018 14:00

item.title: The Power of the German Constitutional Court (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.12.2021)
item.description:
The Federal Constitutional Court was founded 70 years ago. It is one of the most powerful institutions in Germany, along with the federal government, parliament and the Federal President. Often hostile to politics and respected by Germans, it has shaped the Federal Republic. But do these judges have too much power given they don't have a democratic mandate?
From 04.12.2021 21:53

item.title: Henri Guisan - Great Speeches (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.07.2018)
item.description:
June 1940 saw the end of the phony war and Paris falls to the Germans. Although neutral, Switzerland finds itself surrounded and threatened with the possibility of invasion. It falls on General Henri Guisan to form a defensive plan.
From 09.07.2018 12:30

item.title: Urho Kekkonen: Peace and Security in Europe - Great Speeches (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.07.2018)
item.description:
Helsinki July 1975: Finnish president Urho Kekkonen’s intervention at the Conference for Security and Co-operation in Europe sought to overcome the painful divisions of the Cold War in Europe.
From 09.07.2018 16:00

item.title: Wallonia Says No: Paul Magnette - Great Speeches (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.07.2018)
item.description:
On the 14th of October 2016 the Belgian federal state of Wallonia rejected CETA, the trade deal between Canada and the European Union by Waloon first minister Paul Magnette. How did one speech have such an impact on the whole of Europe?
From 09.07.2018 16:00

item.title: Joachim Roncin, the Mind Behind "Je suis Charlie" - Domino Effect (3/4) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (24.08.2021)
item.description:
Joachim Roncin is the artist behind the iconic black and white image ‘Je Suis Charlie’. He was in the middle of an editorial meeting at Stylist when alerts started to come through: a fellow magazine, Charlie Hebdo, had been wiped out in a bloody massacre. Joachim’s image captured the pain of a nation.
From 24.08.2021 20:20

item.title: Birth Control: Emancipation or Forced Sterilisation? - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.09.2021)
item.description:
Looking at history through the prism of one object. In this episode, the intrauterine device (IDU) in plastic or copper brought birth control to the masses in the 20th century. But this form of contraception has not always been a force for women’s liberation.
From 14.09.2021 10:00

item.title: The Suit: Uniform of the Modern Man - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.09.2021)
item.description:
The history of the suit and tie, from the end of the 19th century onwards, overlaps with the Americanisation of the industrial world. Manuel Charpy deciphers the suit's ideal of dynamism and modernity and the social distinctions of the clothes we wear.
From 14.09.2021 10:00

item.title: The Colonial Pith Helmet - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (31.03.2022)
item.description:
In the tropical colonies, Europeans wore a white pith helmet to protect themselves from the sun. This humble piece of headwear came to symbolise colonial oppression and reinforced the separation between coloniser and colonised.
From 31.03.2022 08:00

item.title: Making History - The Hand of Justice (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (13.04.2022)
item.description:
A powerful symbol of justice meted out by the royal hand, the hand of justice played a prominent place in the coronation rituals of the Kings of France. The symbol first emerged in the 13th century to represent how kings of France delegated the management of the justice system to the courts.
From 13.04.2022 00:00

item.title: The Nefertiti Bust: The Birth of an Icon - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.09.2021)
item.description:
In 1912 a German archaeologist discovered the bust of Nefertiti, wife of the Egyptian pharaoh Akhenaten, when he uncovered the workshop of an ancient artist at Amarna. The discovery of this beautiful sculpture caused a sensation at the time and chimed with contemporary ideals of feminine beauty
From 14.09.2021 10:00

item.title: Family Squabbles - The Birth of Christianity (4/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.01.2021)
item.description:
ARTE’s landmark series on the history of religion, produced in 2003. This series tells how Christianity emerged between the death of Jesus and 150 CE. In this episode a conflict tears apart the small community of Jesus’s followers: Stephen, leader of the community is brutally executed.
From 11.01.2021 13:14

item.title: Autochrome: Life in Colour - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (06.11.2021)
item.description:
The Lumière brothers not only invented the cinematograph: in 1903 they also succeeded in fixing colours on glass plates. Looking at those images, time flattens. These long-dead models staring back through a now non-existent lens seem vivid and alive. But thirty years later, colour had once again been drained out of the frame. Historian Adrien Genoudet explains what happened.
From 06.11.2021 05:00

item.title: Napoleon: Snappy Dresser? - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.09.2021)
item.description:
Napoleon's gray frock coat was a way of conveying to Europe that though he was now a statesman, he was first and foremost a man of war. Even more than the legendary bicorne, the frock coat became a piece of visual propaganda, proof of the Emperor's power.
From 16.09.2021 11:16

item.title: A Kingdom That Is Not Coming - The Birth of Christianity (3/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.01.2021)
item.description:
Instead of hiding or fleeing to Galilee, Jesus's disciples congregate in Jerusalem. Why do they run this risk? During his lifetime, what did Jesus’s disciples expect? What do they still hope for after the death of their leader? And what exactly did Jesus mean by the kingdom of god?
From 09.01.2021 00:00

item.title: The Mummy and its Metamorphosis - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (13.01.2022)
item.description:
Mummies are not only from Ancient Egypt, the desire to preserve the dead runs throughout history. 19th century embalming practices, for example, revealed a new relationship to mourning and the afterlife. Historian Anne Carol takes us through our relationship to the body and death.
From 13.01.2022 12:53

item.title: A History of Taxes - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (09.10.2021)
item.description:
The history of tax returns is also the story of how the state slowly became more centralised and more controlling. From historical documents, to the most contemporary and computerised forms, this is the history of income tax returns (and tax evasion).
From 09.10.2021 05:00

item.title: Indienne Fabrics and the Birth of Fast Fashion - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (27.11.2021)
item.description:
In the 18th century, patterned fabrics became fashionable and were used both in dresses and in bourgeois furniture upholstery. This trend was the result of the international cotton trade from India, an exchange that foreshadowed globalisation. Indiennes fabrics are considered the first specimen of "fast fashion", as we know it today.
From 27.11.2021 05:00

item.title: The Wrath of God - The Birth of Christianity (7/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.01.2021)
item.description:
In the First Epistle to the Thessalonians, the oldest text in the New Testament in which he gives his instructions to the Christian community of Thessaloniki, Paul seems to denounces the Jews. Why does Paul do this? Is this the starting point of Christian anti-Semitism?
From 11.01.2021 15:20

item.title: The Passport - A Paper Border - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.09.2021)
item.description:
The object seems recent: its international standardisation is barely a century old, and yet questions of identification and control have never ceased to haunt the history of societies. For the passport was invented to control populations considered dangerous: Vagrants, deserters, illegal immigrants.
From 14.09.2021 10:00

item.title: The Pirate Flag - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.09.2021)
item.description:
The pirate flag flies high at most carnivals and fancy dress parties, but it's got a long and violent history behind it. The scull and crossbones once played an important role in the creation of nation states and the concept of national sovereignty.
From 16.09.2021 11:10

item.title: The Barricade: Fortifying an Insurrection - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.09.2021)
item.description:
Paris, 12 May 1588: the so-called "day of the barricades" marked a high point in the Wars of Religion, pitting Catholics against Protestants in 16th century France and Europe. Prompted by the Catholic League, Parisians piled rubbish and barrels full of stones to block the way of King Henry III's troops.
From 16.09.2021 11:15

item.title: Making History - The Tin Can: Conserve and Survive (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (21.02.2022)
item.description:
Peter Durand invented the tin can, a small but mighty innovation that changed the world. The method meant Western powers were able to feed entire armies all around the world as Europe wrestled for global dominance.
From 21.02.2022 11:08

item.title: The Football Shirt: The Modern Hero's Uniform - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (20.11.2021)
item.description:
The heroicisation of athletes conflates their physical ability with personal economic success. The football shirt is at once a useful everyday object and the stuff of legend. It's the modern day, real life hero's cape.
From 20.11.2021 05:00

item.title: Jesus - The Birth of Christianity (1/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.01.2021)
item.description:
Around 30 CE, Jesus is crucified by the Romans. Three centuries later Christianity becomes the official religion of the Roman Empire. How long did it take for Jesus to become Jesus Christ, son of God? And did Jesus found the church?
From 11.01.2021 18:10

item.title: Mirror, Mirror on the Wall - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.09.2021)
item.description:
Is it possible to write a history of our own reflection? Historian Philippe Artières, reflects on the mirror as an object and the action of observing oneself that for ordinary citizens only dates back to the nineteenth century.
From 14.09.2021 10:00

item.title: When Food Meets Chemistry - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.09.2021)
item.description:
How did meat become a commodity? By transforming beef into a syrupy, energetic material, the chemist Justus von Liebig revolutionised mass nutrition with his extract of meat.
From 16.09.2021 11:30

item.title: Making History - Coal: The Poisonous Black Diamond (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (27.03.2022)
item.description:
Symbol of the industrial revolution at the end of the 18th century, the extraction of coal catapulted the world into the modern era. It also galvanised the labour movement and continues to be burned to this day. But it will accelerate climate change.
From 27.03.2022 05:00

item.title: Paul - The Birth of Christianity (5/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (06.01.2021)
item.description:
Paul, according to the Acts of the Apostles, helped to kill Stephen and then in the persecution of the early Christian Jews. Did Paul convert on the road to Damascus? Who was this New Testament character, both author of the epistles that bear his name and hero of the book of Acts? Why does he call himself the last of the last?
From 06.01.2021 00:00

item.title: Ostraca: A Piece of Clay Means Exile - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (27.07.2021)
item.description:
Ostracism is still commonly used in our contemporary political vocabulary to designate exclusion and has its origins in Ancient Greece. Paulin Ismard, a specialist in the political anthropology of ancient Greece, traces the genealogy of a ritual that founded Athenian democracy.
From 27.07.2021 15:56

item.title: The Council of Jerusalem - The Birth of Christianity (6/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.01.2021)
item.description:
In the middle of the first century CE, the movement of Jesus’s followers spreads amongst Jewish diasporic communities and amongst gentiles. A council meets in Jerusalem to decide on a crucial question: Must one be Jewish to become a Christian?
From 11.01.2021 18:35

item.title: Stone Age Axes - Clearing the Land - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.09.2021)
item.description:
Polished axes from the Neolithic period were the tools used for perhaps the biggest change that man has brought about on Earth: the clearing of the land for agriculture.
From 16.09.2021 11:30

item.title: The Turin Shroud - A Relic for the 20th Century - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (14.09.2021)
item.description:
Patrick Boucheron brings history to life through objects. With the inventions of photography the Turin shroud, a relic venerated for centuries, found a new lease of life as the photographic negatives seemed to confirm its sacred status. A relic in the age of mechanical reproduction.
From 14.09.2021 10:00

item.title: How Chopsticks Made the Chinese - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.09.2021)
item.description:
China, after having been for centuries at the heart of a world where the adoption of Chinese customs, included how they ate, was the main criterion of civilisation, was looked down upon by the West in the 19th century. Historian Clément Fabre traces the history of the humble chopstick through the ages.
From 16.09.2021 11:10

item.title: The Lottery Ball and the Politics of Chance - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.09.2021)
item.description:
Claire Judde de Larivière, a specialist in Renaissance Venice, analyses how the drawing of lots partly reduced corruption and constituted a ritual that united the community of patricians in the Venetian Republic. We also understand what links the ballot box and the lottery box, throughout history.
From 16.09.2021 11:30

item.title: The True Israel - The Birth of Christianity (10/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.01.2021)
item.description:
Around 150 CE Christianity declares itself verus Israel, the true Israel. What consequences does this have for the Jews? And for the nascent Christian religion?
From 11.01.2021 17:00

item.title: Making History - The Crucifix: Purely Christian? (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (12.04.2022)
item.description:
At what point does a cross stop being about the torture of the person upon it and becomes an abstract symbol? In the Middle Ages people didn't shy away from the terrible suffering inflicted upon Jesus. But over time, that suffering was sanitised.
From 12.04.2022 18:15

item.title: The Acts of the Apostles - The Birth of Christianity (8/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.01.2021)
item.description:
Towards the end of the first century CE, the author of the Gospel according to Luke writes another work, the Acts of the Apostles, which tells of the birth of the Christian movement.  How trustworthy is this source as an historic document? And who was it written for?
From 11.01.2021 16:00

item.title: The Parasol and Beach Culture - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (27.07.2021)
item.description:
The parasol or beach umbrella is synonymous with summer beach holidays but it has not always been so. Historian Elsa Devienne tells us the social and cultural history of an object that has appeared on and disappeared from our beaches as fashion, tanning practices and our attitudes to our bodies change.
From 27.07.2021 15:57

item.title: James - The Birth of Christianity (2/10) (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (11.01.2021)
item.description:
In the early gospels James, named as the brother of Jesus, seems to be his successor. Did Jesus really have brothers? And if so why did some of the gospels insist on Mary’s virginity?
From 11.01.2021 18:10

item.title: The Mantle of Roger II of Sicily - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (16.09.2021)
item.description:
In 12th century Sicily King Roger II had a ceremonial cloak made to show his power and magnificence with beautiful Arabic inscriptions adorning its hems. Religious historian Valérie Theis explores the history of this mysterious mantle
From 16.09.2021 11:30

item.title: The Postard - War Hero - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (05.01.2022)
item.description:
Around 4 billion postcards were sent in France during the First World War as soldiers on the front kept in touch with family and loved ones back home. But did these postcards accurately depict what life was like at war?
From 05.01.2022 08:01

item.title: The Amphora - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (13.11.2021)
item.description:
While the shipping container is instantly recognisable in today's era of globalisation, its ancestor in Greco-Roman Antiquity looked very different: it was the amphora. Patrick Boucheron and the historian Sarah Rey reveal the secrets and meanings behind this "simple" terracotta object.
From 13.11.2021 05:00

item.title: Making History - The Hand of Fatima: A Universal Symbol? (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (04.03.2022)
item.description:
As a tattoo or worn as a pendant, the Hamsa or Hand of Fatima can symbolise many things. Originally from North Africa and the Middle East, its symbolism and religious significance varies widely.
From 04.03.2022 05:00

item.title: The Picture Frame - A Window on the Art World - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (08.12.2021)
item.description:
The gilded frame appeared in the Middle Ages transforming a work of art into a picture that could be bought and sold. Historian Charlotte Guichard explains how the invention of the frame made the modern art market, and art collections, possible.
From 08.12.2021 08:00

item.title: Coffins Gain Ground - Making History (Originalversion mit Untertitel) (23.10.2021)
item.description:
